intro: Pedicularis parryi, commonly known as the Parry's lousewort, is a flowering plant native to the high elevations of the western United States and northwestern Mexico. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family, which includes parasitic and hemiparasitic species. The plant typically grows in rocky, alpine environments, often in open meadows or on slopes. Its flowers are usually pink or purple, with a distinctive spurred structure that aids in pollination by insects. The leaves are alternate and often covered in fine hairs, adapting to the harsh conditions of its habitat.
